Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Story: I stared at my phone, the message from my stepmother glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It would mean so much to your father.” My heart thudded. I knew how important this tradition was to them, how much they wanted me to be part of the family, to show I belonged. But my laptop chimed with another notification—an email from my project manager, reminding me that the prototype demo was in two days. The stakeholders were anxious, and my team was counting on me to finalize the design. I could almost hear the disappointment in their voices if I let them down. My mind spun between the warmth of family expectations and the cold, logical demands of engineering. I wanted to be the stepchild who finally fit in, but I was also the engineer who couldn’t afford to miss a deadline. My chest tightened as I realized I couldn’t be in two places at once, and both sides needed me now more than ever.
